review.title: Predicting the consequence of action in digital control state spaces
review.abstract: The objective of this dissertation is to shed light on some fundamental impediments in learning control laws in continuous state spaces. In particular, if one wants to build artificial devices capable to learn motor tasks the same way they learn to classify signals and images, one needs to establish control rules that do not necessitate comparisons between quantities of the surrounding space. We propose, in that context, to take inspiration from the "end effector control" principle, as suggested by neuroscience studies, as opposed to the "displacement control" principle used in the classical control theory.

sections.heading: 1 Problem statement
sections.text: Most machine learning techniques are based on a pattern matching principle, in which representative vectors are constructed from many transitions over large datasets of examples, and the resulting set of prototypes then works like a dictionary of shapes and provides a reduced description of the input data. Projecting the input vectors onto this space of re-description is then intended to facilitate further processing and interpretation of the data. Learning then coincides with the creation of a vocabulary of shapes that serve as keys to the interpretation of the data. However, there are few examples in the literature in which automatic coding algorithms ultimately learn a law of control in a continuous space of action. This difficulty seems to stem from the conceptual separation between the approach of dynamic systems on the one hand and the pattern that fits each other.From the perspective of the dynamic system, a common simplification considers a controller and its environment as a single dynamic system, with a reciprocal coupling between an internal part dedicated to data processing and an internal space that is moving through an external and internal space.

sections.text: Control loops are generally described with two state spaces, namely the control room Xin, whose state at the time is t x in t-Xin, and the physical space Xout, whose state at the time is t xoutt-Xout. sections.heading: 3 Learning to predict
sections.text: However, the realization and implementation of these predictable transformations in a neural circuit (suitable for learning) is proving to be more difficult than expected, mainly due to the lack of a defined (operational) distance in the control room that implements learning, as opposed to physical space that implements actions. In learning, the universality of a learning scheme (its ability to learn any transformation) is mostly based on the use of nonlinear transfer functions in one step (at least) of the data processing path, such as threshold functions, Argmax, signatures, cores, etc. (Haykin, 1999) The many modern learning techniques used in pattern recognition rely on these nonlinear steps to obtain sufficient discriminatory power and extract common features from many samples. Therefore, the pattern matching approach does not guarantee the proportionality of treatments between near and distant parts of physical space.

sections.heading: 5 Concluding remarks
sections.text: A first remark, once brain modeling is considered, is the likely combination of several control principles that serve different purposes in biological systems. If end-effector control happens to have interesting predictive abilities, a counterpart is a certain lack of adaptability to changing conditions. Changes in body inclination, muscle fatigue, or an effector error can have dramatic consequences on the final precision of motion. Parallel and rapidly adaptive control is expected in the cerebellum, with the ability to deflect the fly's motor orders at the time it is sent to the muscles.
